title: Ticket #5729: Allow "for all" for node name for script, retry, etc.
description:
I was just talking with Miron about #1326, and he suggested that a first step is to allow some kind of special "for all" string that's not a regex -- you just either specify an explicit node name, or you get everything in your DAG. This would clearly be easier to implement than regexes, and Miron thinks it might be more understandable for the average user.

Also, it just occurred to me that if you specify this inside a splice, it would only apply to nodes within that splice -- that would give users a way to have a command apply to only a subset of the nodes of their entire workflow, which might make the regex less necessary.

One note about this: whatever the "for each" string is, we'd have to disallow actually having that for a node name...
remarks:
2016-Jun-15 14:33:25 by wenger:
I'm thinking that if the DAG file contains something like 

  SCRIPT PRE _for_all_ ...

that that command will only apply to nodes that have already been defined at that point in the DAG file.

(Hmm -- I'd have to think about whether a "for all" command in a top-level DAG would apply to nodes that are spliced in. Seems like it would be more intuitive for it not do, but I should get some feedback on that, and think about implementation details.)

In terms of implementation, I'm thinking we'd want to write a new method (probably static) in parse.cpp that would be an iterator on the Job objects matching the specified name.

We might want to finish up #4602 before implementing this.

2016-Jun-15 14:43:28 by wenger:
Hmm -- if we want a "for all" command to apply to all nodes, even those defined later in the file, maybe we should just go to a two-pass parsing of the DAG file, where in the first pass we only parse JOB and SUBDAG EXTERNAL commands, and in the second pass we parse everything else. (That would also allow, say, a PARENT/CHILD command to come before some or all of the node definitions.)

2016-Jun-15 15:27:26 by wenger:
Okay, just had a discussion about this with Lauren, and she thinks that a "for all" command should apply to all nodes within a DAG file, including ones that are defined after the "for all" command. (I tend to agree with this -- I think it's easier to understand that applying only to nodes defined before the "for all" command.) We also both agreed that a "for all" command in a DAG file should not apply to nodes within a splice referenced by that DAG file.

(Hmm -- I just thought of something else: should "for all" commands apply to FINAL nodes? Some cannot (e.g., PARENT/CHILD), for some (e.g., SCRIPT) it's not obvious.) I'm tending to think that the "for all" commands should just not apply to FINAL nodes...

See #5732.

2016-Jun-24 11:51:24 by wenger:
Do something like this: 

   Job *Dag::FindAllNodesByName( const char *name );

First call it with a specific node name, then with NULL. So in parse functions it would be like this: 

   const char *nodeName = ...
   while ( Job *node = FindAllNodesByName( nodeName ) ) {
     nodeName = NULL;
     do actual work here...
   }
   if ( nodeName ) {
     error (node not found)...
   }

If you call FindAllNodesByName() with a name other than "ALL_NODES", and that node doesn't exist, FindAllNodesByName() should print an error message. Also, I guess if you call FindAllNodesByName() with "ALL_NODES" and there aren't any nodes, that should probably be an error.

2016-Jul-24 15:47:33 by wenger:
Hmm -- something to think about: what if the user does something like this?: 

  ...
  VARS all_nodes name="$(JOB)"
  ...
  VARS NodeX name="special_name"
  ...

Does the VARS for a specific node override the all_nodes one? If so, I guess we have to parse all of the all_nodes ones first, and then parse the node-specific ones...

2016-Aug-04 16:04:15 by wenger:
Or maybe we just parse VARS, etc., in the order they are in the DAG file, and later ones override earlier ones (I think that's what we do now with node-specific ones).

2016-Aug-04 16:05:17 by wenger:
Probably do this first for VARS -- I think that has the biggest demand...

2016-Aug-05 13:54:19 by wenger:
I currently have this just about finished for VARS (because that seemed like the command for which ALL_NODES is most useful).

Which other commands do we want ALL_NODES to apply to? I'm thinking the following:

  • SCRIPT
  • PRE_SKIP
  • RETRY
  • ABORT-DAG-ON
  • Maybe CATEGORY (could be useful for splices)
  • Maybe PRIORITY (could be useful for splices)

2016-Sep-12 09:51:16 by wenger:
Right now this won't work right for multiple DAGs on the condor_submit_dag command line (ALL_NODES specifications in later DAGs will also apply to already-parsed DAGs).

2016-Sep-12 09:55:56 by wenger:
Hmm -- need to make sure this works right with INCLUDE, too...

2016-Sep-21 10:52:22 by wenger:
The changes for this ticket (on V8_5_gittrac_5729-branch) also include fixes for #4602.
